Firstly, the nature of social housing itself has changed. In the past, social housing was primarily provided by public sector bodies, such as local authorities or government agencies. However, in recent years, there has been a shift towards alternative forms of social housing, such as housing associations and community land trusts.

However, in recent years, the role of social housing has been contracting and changing in many countries. This essay will analyse and explain the changes in the role of social housing, highlighting its decreasing availability, increasing privatization, and shifting focus towards other forms of support.

One of the primary changes in the role of social housing is the decreasing availability of social housing units. Social housing plays a crucial role in many modern welfare states, providing affordable housing options for low-income families, vulnerable populations, and individuals who are homeless. However, in recent years, the role of social housing has been contracting and changing, with many welfare states experiencing significant transformations in the provision and management of social housing. This essay will analyze and explain the changes referred to here, highlighting the implications of these transformations for social housing and its beneficiaries.

In many modern welfare states, social housing is provided by government agencies or non-profit organizations, which own and manage the housing stock.
